questions.question:
Question 1: What is the mechanism of action of dapsone, considering that it is used in the treatment of 
leprosy, fungal infections and, also for immunomodulatory actions?
questions.explanation:
The mechanism of action of dapsone is inhibition of folic acid synthesis. Dapsone [4,4■diaminodiphenylsulphone (DDS)] is a structural analog of para-aminobenzoic acid 
(PABA) and a competitive inhibitor of dihydropteroate synthase in the folate pathway. It is weakly 
bactericidal and can cause mild hemolysis, and rarely anemia or psychosis. DDS syndrome is a rare side effect of dapsone therapy in leprosy patients which starts after 5-6 
weeks of starting dapsone and leads to exfoliative dermatitis, hepatosplenomegaly, 
lymphadenopathy, fever and hepatitis and may be fatal. It is also called 'five-week dermatitis'.

questions.question: Question 2: Dapsone would not be helpful in which of the following patients?

options.a: HIV positive patient with CD4<100 and IgG positive for Toxoplasma
options.c: HIV positive patient with Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia

questions.explanation:
Dapsone is not used in the treatment of schistosomiasis. Praziquantel is the drug recommended 
for this condition. Dapsone with pyrimethamine and leucovorin can be given for prophylaxis of Toxoplasma 
encephalitis in HIV patients with CD4<100. Along with trimethoprim, it can be given for 
prophylaxis and treatment of Pneumocystis pneumonia. However, cotrimoxazole remains the 
drug of choice in both conditions. The uses of dapsone are: Infections • Leprosy • Pneumocystis jerovecii infections (prophylaxis and treatment) • Malaria • Toxoplasma gondi infections (prophylaxis) Inflammatory conditions • Dermatitis herpetiformis • Pemphigoid • Relapsing chondritis • Linear IgA bullous disease

questions.explanation:
The given image of a man with nodular lesions on his face depicts lepromatous leprosy and is 
treated by standard multidrug regimen (MDR-WHO recommended) for 12 months. It consists of: 586

questions.question: Question 4: All of the following are administered under supervision in India except?
questions.explanation:
Dapsone is administered daily in both multibacillary and paucibacillary leprosy without 
supervision. Clofazimine is indicated as a once-monthly supervised dose (300 mg) and daily unsupervised 
doses (50 mg) in multibacillary leprosy and paucibacillary leprosy. Pyrizanamide is an ATT drug which is administered under direct supervision. Rifampicin is indicated as a once-monthly supervised dose for both multibacillary and 
paucibacillary leprosy.

questions.question:
Question 5: A patient presented with multiple hypopigmented skin lesions and loss of sensation over the 
lesions. What is the most bactericidal drug for the condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of leprosy and rifampicin is the most bactericidal 
anti-leprotic drug. Clofazimine and dapsone are bacteriostatic agents, while ethionamide is not indicated in leprosy.

questions.question: Question 6: What is the most bactericidal anti leprotic drug amongst the given drugs?
questions.explanation:
Ofloxacin is the most bactericidal anti leprotic drug amongst the given drugs. It exhibits high activity against M. leprae, and it is being used in alternative multidrug therapy 
(MDT) regimens in rifampicin-resistant cases. As a component of MDT, it has been found to 
hasten the bacteriological and clinical response. Among the macrolides, clarithromycin has activity against leprosy bacilli and is used for 
alternative MDT in cases resistant to both rifampicin and fluoroquinolones. Azithromycin shows 
activity against Mycobacterium avium complex but not lepra bacilli. Note: Rifampicin is the most potent bactericidal anti leprotic drug.

questions.question:
Question 7: Thalidomide is useful in the treatment of which of the following conditions? 583 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Thalidomide is useful in the treatment of erythema nodosum leprosum (ENL) or type 2 lepra 
reaction. It is indicated in recurring and persistent ENL lesions despite the completion of at least 
two courses of glucocorticoid therapy. 587 
Sold by @itachibot Thalidomide is not effective in type 1 lepra reaction. If type 1 reactions occur after initiation of 
antimycobacterial therapy, they are termed reversal reactions and it is histologically more 
tuberculoid. When they occur before the initiation, they are termed downgrading reactions and it 
is histologically more lepromatous.

questions.question:
Question 8: A patient with borderline leprosy develops severe type 1 lepra reaction during the course of 
his multidrug therapy. What would be the most appropriate treatment for him?
questions.explanation: The most appropriate therapy for severe type 1 lepra reactions is glucocorticoids. Clofazimine, though effective in type 1 lepra reaction, is less efficacious than glucocorticoids. Thalidomide and plasmapheresis are not indicated in the treatment of type 1 lepra reaction.

questions.question:
Question 9: A patient with leprosy, who is on multidrug therapy, presents with painful raised lesions on 
his forehead as shown in the image. Which of the following must be avoided in his condition?
questions.explanation:
The presence of tender, erythematous, subcutaneous nodules as seen in the image is suggestive 
of Type II lepra reaction in which rifampicin must be avoided. Rifampicin is highly bactericidal to M. leprae and results in high kill rates and massive release of 
bacterial antigens and may aggravate type 2 lepra reactions (also called erythema nodosum 
leprosum). Options A and B: Clofazimine and corticosteroids are indicated in both type 1 and type 2 lepra 
reactions. Option C: Thalidomide is indicated in type 2 lepra reactions.

questions.question:
Question 10: A patient presents with complaints of reddish-black discolouration of skin and body 
secretions. Which anti-mycobacterial agent can cause this condition?
questions.explanation:
Reddish-black discolouration of skin and body secretions is observed with the use of clofazimine. Clofazimine has good penetration into many tissues and results in reddish-black discolouration of 
skin and body secretions. This may take a long time to resolve.

questions.question: Question 11: Rifampin is not active against which of the following Mycobacterial species?

options.a: An elderly woman with avian influenza

questions.explanation:
Rifampin is not active against Mycobacterium abscessus. It is innately resistant to rifampicin. First-line therapy for Mycobacterium abscessus includes cefoxitin (or imipenem) + amikacin + 
clarithromycin. Rifampicin is effective against Mycobacterium avium complex, Mycobacterium leprae, and 
Mycobacterium kansasii. (Options A, B, D) 588 
Sold by @itachibot Anti-virals (Non-retroviral)
